title: Family heartbreak as man, 22, who overcame difficult childhood takes his own life
text:

The heartbroken family of a young man turning his life around have urged others struggling to seek help after he took his own life.

An inquest has heard how Nathan Taylor was discovered by police at his Hull home back in March.

A conclusion of suicide was reached after the 22-year-old was reported missing by his concerned mum eight months ago.

He was “loved by everyone” as he got his life back on track following a challenging childhood.

He spent most of his youth in and out of care and foster homes due to his behaviour being “unmanageable”.

Although it's too late for Nathan, his family want other people suffering with depression to speak about their issues.

(Image: Peter Harbour)

His sister Lucy James-Guest told HullLive : “He liked making people happy. He was really funny.

“One of my favourite memories of him was when we used to go to The Pit and he sat in what you would put plant pots in and he got stuck.

“We couldn’t ring the fire brigade because we were laughing that much so he had to call them to get him out.

“At the time he was mad at us but in the end he found it funny."

She added: “Just talk. Talk to someone you feel comfortable with. He would keep it to himself. I think it is fair to say out of all of his siblings I was the closest to him and he would never tell me about it.

(Image: Google Maps)

“He was more bothered about what was going on in my life and was more bothered about others than himself."

As he pieced his life back together, he secured his dream job working with Hull City Council as a Youth Champion, helping young people in care and guiding them on to better paths.

His mum said: “He was dead proud of where he was working. He showed me his new suit and said ‘what do you think mum?’

“He was starting to get somewhere job wise. It was a job he was chuffed to bits with. I was immensely proud.”

The Samaritans is available 24/7 if you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling 116 123, email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter.
description: Nathan Taylor spent years battling depression but was turning his life around, an inquest heard
